body: @xqdan @ZihengJiang @tmoreau89 please review.

Discussed some more in person with Tianqi as well as some informal feedback about the PR with @zhiics. After the following discussion we all agree we can remove unnecessary concepts and ship a minimal definition of pass and the pass manager. 

The pass interface will be Module -> Module with an optional PassContext object which will contain things such as the error reporter. User passes can ignore this if they want, but it will provide value to passes to tap into common functionality such as errors and diagnostics. 

We will have a single pass base class that contains the metadata about passes and a pass method of type `Module run(Module&, PassContext*)`. We can build higher level notions on top of this, and the goal of the pass manager is to schedule and execute these passes. 

We believe this satisfies the design criteria everyone has laid out above.

Here is the situation we are facing:
`PackedFunc` can only pass `TVMArgs`-family arguments, like `tvm::NDArray`.
Thus, an external call will also only get a `tvm::NDArray` back.
In `tvm::NDArray` the `Container *data_` is protected, so we cannot get `data_->array_type_index_`.

To resolve this issue, it will be desirable to have a trait to force users to define a static indicator for each subclass of `NDArray` and `Container`, and provide an `as<Type>()` method to cast it to its corresponding subclass.

Thanks everybody for your valuable comments and suggestions. I've updated the PR #2546 accordingly. I will send another RFC with the stuff we want to focus on after the framework of pass manager is merged. I appreciate your time to review it.

(Outdated, don't read)

Added a type trait `array_type_index`, which is only enabled to NDArray and subclasses of NDArray. 

A subclass of NDArray should do the following things in their own codebase, without modifying TVM.
1) specialize the type trait `array_type_index`
2) define implicit conversion from `TVMArgValue` to itself, so as to enable implicit conversion.
3) define a constructor from `TVM::runtime::NDArray::Container`

@sgrechanik-h Thanks for the hard work on proposing and bringing in the implementation, this seems to be an RFC that many folks are interested in.

I have no doubt on the possibility to make a correct and efficient tensor expression auto diff. The key issue we need to address first is how can we make a clear set of APIs and namespaces so that:
- We have a clear separation between relay's grad and the current tensor expression one
- Have a clear indication for frontend user to use relay's grad, while use tensor expression one for the operator impl
- Have a consistent API so a user does not get confused when using one or another.
- Because the primary support for end to end grad is in relay, we want to name the files clearly(e.g. tvm/autodiff-> tvm/expr_grad.h) to make that distinction, so it is more clear that relay is the entry point of tvm stack's differentiation.


These discussions and decision are important because they will affect how users will use the API, as per https://docs.tvm.ai/contribute/code_review.html#deliberate-on-api-and-data-structures

I suggest we discuss them, reach consensus before we move on 

cc @merrymercy @jroesch @yzhliu @junrushao1994 @ZihengJiang @grwlf @dmlc/tvm-committer
Sorry for delayed comment, I posted some updated thoughts in the RFC. If zero-elimination is independent of this patch, I would recommend creating a separate PR to merge that in first.

Hi @jdavies-huawei , I like the idea to extend TensorComputeOp with scalar inputs, but for the API. It would be better we can use `tfunc(A[i, 0:n], i*i)` directly instead of having another parameter called `scalar_inputs`
Just out of curiosity, in what situation we need to use `tensorize` in `TensorComputeOp`?

@ZihengJiang What if we have multiple tensor inputs and multiple scalar inputs? Do you suggest that we should be able to interleave them and write something like `tfunc(A[i, 0:n], i*i, i+1, B[i, 0:n])`?

We have used `TensorComputeOp` to put some fine-grained tensor computation inside a black box (for example, a 4x4 matmul). However, our hardware also supports a coarse-grained version of the same tensor computation (for example, a 16x16 matmul), and that is expressible by a loopnest around the fine-grained version. What we would like to do is to `tensorize` to replace the loopnest of fine-grained version with a single invocation of the coarse-grained version. (The actual tensor computation we are currently using this technique for is not matmul. I'm using matmul as an example only)

The reason we use the fine-grained version in our tensor computation is that it gives us more flexibility. Does that answer your question?

Right. The simple solution is to check in `c_runtime_api.rs`. I'll see if bindgen works yet with non-host targets.

I think we have seen this issue before, but I am not sure how we should fix it in the tutorial. Does the workaround of changing `localhost` to a real address such as `127.0.0.1` work for you? macOS seems to have many more network interfaces than other systems we have tried AutoTVM on, so maybe there is something strange when resolving `localhost`.

Here are the things to discuss I came up with.

## Naming

Concerning names, here is a list of things in the tensor expression AD that we might want to rename:
* C++ files `include/tvm/autodiff.h` and `src/pass/autodiff.cc`, and a python module `tvm.autodiff`.  `autodiff` is the most important thing to rename. I'd suggest something like `tensordiff`, `tensor_expr_diff`, `tensor_expr_ad`. I think using just `expr` without `tensor` may be a little bit confusing, since there are exprs in Relay too. Using `grad` vs `diff` is a matter of taste, I guess, `diff` seems more general though.
* The main user-facing python function `tvm.autodiff.differentiate`, reexported as `tvm.differentiate` for convenience. I would suggest keeping its name as is, however we probably shouldn't reexport it, to avoid confusion.
* Some more or less internal C++ functions and data structures (`Differentiate`, `Jacobian`, `DiffBuildingBlock`, [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/5ae4ac1c352de4e893997c8d316eb5822cc563f9/include/tvm/autodiff.h)).  They live under `tvm::ir::` in C++ and are exported into `tvm.autodiff` in python.  I would also suggest keeping their names, however we probably should create a separate namespace for them in C++, like `tvm::autodiff`.
* The relay/autodiff integration file `src/relay/op/autodiff_integration.cc`. Its name will be changed when we rename `autodiff`. Not sure about the `_integration` part.
* The relay/autodiff integration op `autogenerated_gradient`. Not sure, suggestions are welcome.
* Functions `relay._ir_pass.AutogeneratePrimalGradient` and `relay._ir_pass.AutogeneratePrimalGradientForAll`. Not sure.

## API

The main thing to discuss here is the python function `tvm.autodiff.differentiate`. Recently I decided that its gradient overriding mechanism is rather difficult to use, and tried to improve it.  Not sure if it's better now, however let's discuss the new version. Its signature and docstring may be found [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/5ae4ac1c352de4e893997c8d316eb5822cc563f9/python/tvm/autodiff.py#L54), Here is just short description:

```python 
def differentiate(output, inputs=None, head=None, override=None, fdiff=None): 
    """Perform reverse-mode automatic differentiation.  
```

Parameters:
* `output : Tensor` - The tensor to differentiate.
* `inputs : List[Tensor]` - The list of input tensors. When the list is empty or None, will perform differentiation wrt all tensors the output depends on.
* `head : Tensor`, optional - The adjoint of the output. By default full Jacobians will be computed (or simply gradients in the case of a scalar output).
* `override` - A dict describing how to override differentiation for certain tensors (see the link).
* `fdiff` - The function performing differentiation and multiplication of single tensors, by default `tvm.autodiff.DiffBuildingBlock` is used.

The returned value of the function is an instance of [DifferentiationResult](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/5ae4ac1c352de4e893997c8d316eb5822cc563f9/python/tvm/autodiff.py#L8).  It mimics a list of gradients (corresponding to inputs) but also contains two other fields: `adjoints` and `adjoint_summands` to access intermediate adjoints.

Several issues to discuss:
* The name of the `head` parameter. May be it'd better be called `output_adjoint` or `output_gradient` or, more precisely, `gradient_wrt_output`, although I tend to avoid the word "gradient" since we don't require the final output to be scalar.
* The gradient overriding mechanism is still quite obscure, maybe we should remove it from this function completely (the corresponding parameters may be retained in the C++ function `Differentiate`).
* The `fdiff` parameter, however, is much easier to understand, so I suggest retaining it.
* Probably we should support multiple outputs, since differentiating them one by one may be less efficient.

Another important function is the C++ counterpart, [tvm::ir::Differentiate](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/5ae4ac1c352de4e893997c8d316eb5822cc563f9/include/tvm/autodiff.h#L143) This function is for developers though. Currently my only suggestion is that we might want to support multiple outputs and heads.

## Relay integration API

The user mostly needs two functions: ([code here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/5ae4ac1c352de4e893997c8d316eb5822cc563f9/src/relay/op/autodiff_integration.cc#L189)):
- `AutogeneratePrimalGradient(op_name, plevel)` - override FPrimalGradient for the given operation (with the given plevel, 100 by default)
- `AutogeneratePrimalGradientForAll(plevel)` - override FPrimalGradient for every existing operation. The plevel here is 5 by default, so it shouldn't override gradients for operations with FPrimalGradient already defined.

The operation representing the generated gradients currently takes a single tuple as input and returns a single tuple as output ([here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/5ae4ac1c352de4e893997c8d316eb5822cc563f9/src/relay/op/autodiff_integration.cc#L140)).  The attributes of the operation are as follows:
* `original_op : Op` - The original operation.
* `original_attrs : Attrs` - The attributes of the original operation.
* `original_out_type : Type`, optional - The type of the original expression. 

However, I think this operation should be considered an implementation detail, and the stability of its attributes, inputs and outputs shouldn't be relied upon.

@vinx13 @Laurawly @zhreshold @kevinthesun please comment if we have reach consensus on the API

@kazimuth appreciate your upcoming contributions in advance!

Great questions :)

> what's the relationship between ...

1.  Everything starts from [dlpack's `DLTensor`](https://github.com/dmlc/dlpack/blob/master/include/dlpack/dlpack.h#L111:L147) as a common tensor/ndarray format for DL frameworks (adopted by Apache MXNet and Pytorch).

2. TVM uses the type alias [`TVMArray` for `DLTensor`](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/include/tvm/runtime/c_runtime_api.h#L120).

3. [`TVMArrayHandle` is an opaque pointer to `TVMArray`](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/include/tvm/runtime/c_runtime_api.h#L123).

4. In frontends (Rust/Python/Java) they define `NDArray` wrapper (struct/class) around `TVMArrayHandle` with more info such as `is_view`.

5. Rust has the luxury of defining its own `ndarray/tensor` in runtime.

6. There's Rust's crate [ndarray](https://github.com/rust-ndarray/ndarray) which we use here to interact with our own `Tensor/NDArray`. Similar to `numpy.ndarray` vs. `mxnet.NDArray`/`pytorch.Tensor`.

7. `NDArrayContainer` is runtime managed NDArray and it's *not* supported in Rust frontend `Function` for now. See [#1418](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1418) for more info.

> Also, do you intend to unify `Function` and `PackedFunc`? I'm still not certain if they do the same thing or not.

Rust frontend `Function` (like `NDArray`) contains a `TVMFunctionHandle` of  [C++ PackedFunc](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/include/tvm/runtime/packed_func.h#L53:L119). Rust frontend optimum representation of `C++ PackedFunc` is `fn(&[TVMArgValue]) -> Result<TVMRetValue>` (which you can use in `register_global_func!` macro to register Rust's packed function as a callback to C++ backend) because first [`fn is a (safe) primitive function pointer type constructor and is already Fn + Pointer + Send + Sync + ...`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.fn.html) and  second it captures the `Result`. Runtime representation is [`Box<Fn(&[TVMArgValue]) -> TVMRetValue + Send + Sync>`](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/rust/runtime/src/packed_func.rs#L15) as direct translation of `std::function<void (TVMArgs args, TVMRetValue* rv)>;`. It's in this PR TODO to change it so that function can capture `Result`.

LGTM

Good effort on simplifying the interface proposal. I still think we need more thoughts :) So far in the current design, there are two-level of pass structures with inconsistent interfaces:

- Pass: which is the low-level transformation with meta-data, declares requirements.
   - Exposes a (Module, PassContext -> Module) public interface
- Optimizer: composes the passes, 
   - Mutates its internal module, hosts states.
   - The name(optimizer) can confuse the user(due to the dual meaning of optimization)

The reason that I do not like the current design is that it forces everything to the optimize interface, while optimizer itself do is NOT a pass. A user has to learn two concepts: Pass and Optimize, more importantly, both of them are somewhat different from Module->Module.

We should learn lessons from deep learning systems(```torch.nn``` or ```gluon.Block```). Take gluon, for example, each Block is a ```Tensor->Tensor``` transformation. We can compose the Blocks by creating new blocks, importantly, after composing Block together, the result is still a Block, and a user can simply treat this as a ```Tensor->Tensor function```.

So I really want us to come up with a design, which corresponds to ```gluon.Block```, except for Pass. 

A user only has to learn one concept: Pass(coresponds to gluon.Block).  It has a few concepts:
   -  A Module->Module call (operator() ) function
   - Some meta-data about dependencies.
   - Perhaps optional SetPassContext to setup context(there are pros and cons about pass PassContext as the argument of operator() vs as a setter)

A PassManager itself is a Pass(analogy to nn.Sequential), which automatically resolves dependencies in its internal implementation. It again exposes a Module->Module interface, its meta-data dependency requirement is empty. 

- A pass manager itself can again be composed into another Pass Manager sequence of transformations(because it is a Pass).
- A user can simply invoke the composed Pass as a Module->Module function.
